caption: This is the fountain monument situated at the southern end of the Garden of the Grand Explorers. It was designed by Gabriel Davioud and features striking sculptural work by Jean-Baptiste Carpeaux and colleagues. The fountain was unveiled in 1874.  What you see is a bronze sphere being held by four females representing (Europe, Asia, Africa and America). They each twist and contort themselves while holding the sphere upward. From below horses rise from the basin. Water spouts from dolphins and turtles evenly spaced within the basin.  It is a nice fountain monument well worth spending a few minutes to enjoy if planning to pass by the  Garden of the Grand Explorers.

Another beautiful landmark to place on your itinerary.  If you identify all of the beautiful landmarks around Paris and then make it a point to walk from one to the next you really get an opportunity to see so much of Paris with little treats of landmarks along the way.

Absolutely breathtaking, with views across the entire square and gardens if you ever want to take a walk in a Parisian park I highly recommend starting your walk from this point because you will enjoy all the sculptures and structures around the park, and while we are there If you are you could pay a nice visit to the pantheon.

A truly special place in Paris. The fountain is symbolic and beautiful. We got engaged at this exact spot in April 2001. We try and visit every time we get a chance to visit Paris. It is a very special place in our hearts. Our special place in this beautiful city. ‚ô•Ô∏èüí¶ ‚Ä¶
Not opened and dirty. Has some beautiful turtle sculptures.
Beautiful park. Open-air public (/free) work-out area for calisthenics.

This monument is a monumental fountain located in the Jardin Marco Polo, south of the Jardin du Luxembourg in the 6th arrondissement of Paris, with sculpture by Jean-Baptiste Carpeaux and It is also known as the Fontaine des Quatre-Parties-du-Monde, for the four parts of the world embodied by its female figures, or simply the Fontaine Carpeaux. The entrance to the garden to admire this landmark is free and you can also relax yourself on surrounding benches. I suggest a quick stop here.

A very impressive fountain also known as the Four Parts of the World fountain. There are four figures holding up an orb standing on a large central pedestal which is immediately surrounded by wild looking horses and there is a large moat of water surrounding them and there are cute turtle sculptures in the moat. There fountain is in a large park that connects to Jardin Luxembourg to the north.

Monumental fountain in continuous operation by Jean-Batiste Carpeaux (1827-1875). Dancing female figures represent Europe, Asia, America & Africa whose enslaved chained ankle is depicted as being held fast by the figure representing America.
When visiting the Jardin de Luxembourg make sure to walk to this fountain. It‚Äôs worth it!
Nice serene place to scroll through and relax. The stone is cool so you stay cool even when it is hot
Well worth the short walk from the main part of the gardens. Great views from any angle and nice place to relax for a while.
Very nice fountain and small park just south of Luxembourg Garden
Loved this little park, had some great play areas for the kids. Really chilled out place to stop and relax

Delightful park with kids playing and green grass. Near Cafe deLilas which was very pleasant
The architectural design is unbelievably beautiful!
Impressive fountain with beautiful sculpture, also called fountain of the four parts of the world. Worth seeing.

The Fontaine de l‚ÄôObservatoire is a monumental fountain located in Jadin Marco Polo in Paris with Sculpture by Jean-Baptiste Carpeaux (1827-1875). It was dedicated in 1874 and is also known for the Four Parts of the World Sculpture embodied by Female figures. The Four parts represent Europe, Asia, Africa & America. A stamps was issued by La Poste on this Fountain.
